    question => string (1368) "Does the Profit and Loss Account (or the top half of the SCI) include the fo...
    $value[1]['question']
    Does the Profit and Loss Account (or the top half of the SCI) include the following headings where applicable:
<ul>
    <li>Revenue, presenting separately interest revenue calculated using the effective interest method;</li>
    <li>Gains and losses arising from the derecognition of financial assets measured at amortised cost;</li>
    <li>Finance costs;</li>
    <li>Impairment losses (including reversals of impairment losses or impairment gains) determined in accordance with Section 5.5 of IFRS 9;</li>
    <li>Share of the profit or loss of associates and joint ventures accounted for using the equity method;</li>
    <li>If a financial asset is reclassified out of the amortised cost measurement category so that it is measured at fair value through profit or loss, any gain or loss arising from a difference between the previous amortised cost of the financial asset and its fair value at the reclassification date (as defined in IFRS 9); </li>
    <li>If a financial asset is reclassified out of the fair value through other comprehensive income measurement category so that it is measured at fair value through profit or loss, any cumulative gain or loss previously recognised in other comprehensive income that is reclassified to profit or loss;</li>
    <li>Tax expense; and</li>
    <li>A single amount of discontinuing operations?</li>
</ul>

    question => UTF-8 string (971) "<b>Revenue from Contracts with Customers</b> <p>IFRS 15 Revenue from Contrac...
    $value[9]['question']
    <b>Revenue from Contracts with Customers</b>
<p>IFRS 15 Revenue from Contracts with Customers is mandatory for accounting periods commencing on/after 1 January 2018. The disclosure requirements are <b><u>much</u></b> more substantial than those previouslSy required by IAS 18 and IAS 11. </p>
<p>All disclosures required under IFRS 15 have been listed below in this section, rather than split between the SCI, Statement of Financial Position and Accounting Policies sections of the Checklist. It is considered that, in the circumstances of the significant additional disclosures required, it is more straightforward to provide the disclosure requirements in one section. </p>
<p><b>First time adoption of IFRS 15 will also require additional transitional disclosures; see question 5.2 of Section 8 – “<span style="color:blue;"><u>Accounting Policies and Estimation Techniques</u></span>” below. This will require completion of a supplementary checklist. </b></p>

    question => UTF-8 string (1649) "Has revenue recognised from contracts with customers been disaggregated into...
    $value[16]['question']
    Has revenue recognised from contracts with customers been disaggregated into categories that depict how the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows are affected by economic factors? 
<p>NB: IFRS 15 does not prescribe any specific factors to be used as a basis for disaggregating revenue. Guidance is provided in Appendix B “Application Guidance”. Paragraph B87 states that “this disclosure depends on the facts and circumstances that pertain to the entity’s contracts with customers. Some entities may need to use more than one type of category to meet the objective in paragraph 114 for disaggregating revenue. Other entities may meet the objective by using only one type of category to disaggregate revenue”.</p>
<p>Paragraph B89 provides examples of categories that might be appropriate which include, but are not limited to, all of the following:</p>
<ol type="a">
    <li>type of good or service (for example, major product lines);</li>
    <li>geographical region (for example, country or region);</li>
    <li>market or type of customer (for example, government and non-government customers);</li>
    <li>type of contract (for example, fixed-price and time-and-materials contracts);</li>
    <li>contract duration (for example, short-term and long-term contracts);</li>
    <li>timing of transfer of goods or services (for example, revenue from goods or services transferred to customers at a point in time and revenue from goods or services transferred over time); and</li>
    <li>sales channels (for example, goods sold directly to consumers and goods sold through intermediaries).</li>
</ol>

    question => string (1000) "Has an explanation been given of the significant changes in contract assets ...
    $value[21]['question']
    Has an explanation been given of the significant changes in contract assets and contract liabilities?
<p>Examples of changes in contract asset and contract liability balances include:</p>
<ul>
    <li>changes due to business combinations;</li>
    <li>cumulative catch-up adjustments to revenue that affect the corresponding contract asset or contract liability, including adjustments arising from a change in the measure of progress, a change in an estimate of the transaction price (including any changes in the assessment of whether an estimate of variable consideration is constrained) or a contract modification;</li>
    <li>impairment of a contract asset;</li>
    <li>a change in the time frame for a right to consideration to become unconditional (i.e. for a contract asset to be reclassified to a receivable); and</li>
    <li>a change in the time frame for a performance obligation to be satisfied (i.e. for the recognition of revenue arising from a contract liability).</li>
</ul>

    Has disclosure been given of the entity’s performance obligations in contracts with customers, including a description of all of the following:
<ul>
    <li>when the entity typically satisfies its performance obligations (for example, upon shipment, upon delivery, as services are rendered or upon completion of service), including when performance obligations are satisfied in a bill-and-hold arrangement;</li>
    <li>the significant payment terms (for example, when payment is typically due, whether the contract has a significant financing component, whether the consideration amount is variable and whether the estimate of variable consideration is typically constrained in accordance with paragraphs 56–58 of IFRS 15);</li>
    <li>the nature of the goods or services that the entity has promised to transfer, highlighting any performance obligations to arrange for another party to transfer goods or services (i.e. if the entity is acting as an agent);</li>
    <li>obligations for returns, refunds and other similar obligations; and</li>
    <li>types of warranties and related obligations?</li>
</ul>
<i>This disclosure is likely to be given as an accounting policy. </i>

    question => UTF-8 string (1130) "Has disclosure of the following been given in relation to the entity’s remai...
    $value[25]['question']
    Has disclosure of the following been given in relation to the entity’s remaining performance obligations:
<ul>
    <li>the aggregate amount of the transaction price allocated to the performance obligations that are unsatisfied (or partially unsatisfied) as of the end of the reporting period; and</li>
    <li>an explanation of when the entity expects to recognise this amount as revenue, either:
        <ol type="i">
            <li>on a quantitative basis using the time bands that would be most appropriate for the duration of the remaining performance obligations; or</li>
            <li>by using qualitative information?</li>
        </ol>
    </li>
</ul>
<p><i>NB: As a practical expedient, an entity need not disclose this information for a performance obligation if either of the following conditions is met:</i></p>
<ol type="a">
    <li><i>the performance obligation is part of a contract that has an original expected duration of one year or less; or</i></li>
    <li><i>the entity recognises revenue from the satisfaction of the performance obligation in accordance with paragraph B16.</i></li>
</ol>

    <li>the transaction price and the amounts allocated to performance obligations (see paragraph 126).</li>
</ul>

    question => UTF-8 string (5114) "<b>Impairment ~ Goodwill and Intangible Fixed Assets with Indefinite Useful ...
    $value[65]['question']
    <b>Impairment ~ Goodwill and Intangible Fixed Assets with Indefinite Useful Lives</b><br>
NB: Where, in certain circumstances, detailed calculations are carried forward and used in the current year’s consideration of impairment in accordance with IAS 36 (paragraphs 24 to 99), the disclosure requirements of paragraphs 134 and 135 noted below relate to these calculations.
<p>Has the following been disclosed for each cash-generating unit (group of units) for which the carrying amount of goodwill or intangible assets with indefinite useful lives allocated to that unit (group of units) is significant in comparison with the entity’s total carrying amount of goodwill or intangible assets with indefinite useful lives:</p>
<ul>
    <li>the carrying amount of goodwill allocated to the unit (group of units);</li>
    <li>the carrying amount of intangible assets with indefinite useful lives allocated to the unit (group of units);</li>
    <li>the basis on which the unit’s (group of units’) recoverable amount has been determined (i.e. value in use or fair value less costs of disposal);</li>
    <li>if the unit’s (group of units’) recoverable amount is based on value in use:
        <ul>
            <li>each key assumption on which management has based its cash flows projections for the period covered by the most recent budget / forecasts.  Key assumptions are those to which the unit’s (group of units’) recoverability is most sensitive;</li>
            <li>a description of management’s approach to determining the value(s) assigned to each key assumption, whether those value(s) reflect past experience or, if appropriate, are consistent with external sources of information, and, if not, why they differ from past experience or external sources of information;</li>
            <li>the period over which management has projected cash flows based on financial budgets / forecasts approved by management and, when a period >5yrs is used for a cash-generating unit (groups of units), an explanation of why that longer period is justified;</li>
            <li>the growth rate used to extrapolate cash flow projections beyond the period covered by the most recent budgets / forecasts, and the justification for using any growth rate that exceeds the long-term average growth rate for the products, industries, or country or countries in which the entity operates, or for the market to which the unit (group of units) is dedicated;</li>
            <li>the discount rate(s) applied to the cash flow projection.</li>
        </ul>
    </li>
    <li>if the unit’s (group of units’) recoverable amount is based on fair value less costs of disposal, the valuation technique(s) used to measure fair value less cost to disposal
        <ul>
            <li>If not measured using a quoted price for an identical unit (group of units’):
                <ul>
                    <li>each assumption on which the management has based its determination of fair value less costs of disposal.  Key assumptions are those to which the unit’s (group of units’) recoverable amount is most sensitive;</li>
                    <li>a description of management’s approach to determining the value (or values) assigned to each key assumption, whether those values reflect past experience or, if appropriate, are consistent with external sources of information, and if not, how and why they differ from past experience or external sources of information;</li>
                    <li>the level of fair value hierarchy (see IFRS 13) within which the fair value measurement is categorised in its entirety;</li>
                    <li>if there has been a change in valuation techniques, the change and the reason for making it.</li>
                </ul>
            </li>
            <li>If fair value less costs of disposal is measured using discounted cash flow projections then the following need to be disclosed:
                <ul>
                    <li>the period over which management has projected cash flows;</li>
                    <li>the growth rate used to extrapolate cash flow projections;</li>
                    <li>the discount rate(s) applied to the cash flow projections;</li>
                </ul>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </li>
    <li>If a reasonably possible change in a key assumption on which management has based its determination of the unit’s (group of units’) recoverable amount would cause the unit’s (group of units’) carrying amount to exceeds its recoverable amount:
        <ul>
            <li>the amount by which the unit’s (group of units’) recoverable amount exceeds it carrying amount;</li>
            <li>the value assigned to the key assumptions;</li>
            <li>the amount by which the value assigned to key assumptions must change, after incorporating any consequential effects of the change on the other variables used to measure recoverable amount, in order for the unit’s (group of units’) recoverable amount to equal its carrying amount?</li>
        </ul>
    </li>
</ul>

<ul>
    <li>that fact;</li>
    <li>aggregate carrying value of goodwill or intangible with indefinite useful lives allocated to those units (groups of units) ;</li>
    <li>additionally, if the recoverable amounts of any of those units (groups of units) are based on the same key assumption(s) and the aggregate carrying amount of goodwill or intangible assets with indefinite useful lives allocated to them is significant in comparison with the entity’s total carrying amount of goodwill or intangible assets with indefinite useful lives, an entity shall disclose that fact, together with:
        <ul>
            <li>the aggregate carrying amount of goodwill allocated to those units (groups of units);</li>
            <li>the aggregate carrying amount of intangible assets with indefinite useful lives allocated to those units (group of units);</li>
            <li>a description of the key assumptions;</li>
            <li>a description of management’s approach to determining the value(s) assigned to the key assumption(s), whether those value(s) reflect past experience or, if appropriate, are consistent with external sources of information, and if not, how and why they differ from past experience or external sources of information;</li>
            <li>if a reasonably possible change in the key assumption(s) would cause the aggregate of the units’ (groups of units’) carrying amounts to exceed the aggregate of their recoverable amounts:
                <ul>
                    <li>the amount by which the aggregate of the units’ (groups of units’) recoverable amounts exceed the aggregate of their carrying amounts;</li>
                    <li>the value(s) assigned to the key assumption(s);</li>
                    <li>the amount by which the value(s) assigned to the key assumption(s) must change, after incorporating any consequential effects of the change on the other variables used to measure recoverable amount, in order for the aggregate of the units’ (groups of units’) recoverable amount to be equal to the aggregate of their carrying amounts?</li>
                </ul>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </li>
</ul>

    question => string (1305) "Have the major components of tax expense (income) been disclosed separately?...
    $value[83]['question']
    Have the major components of tax expense (income) been disclosed separately?
<p>NB:  Components of tax expense (income) may include:</p>
<ul>
    <li>current tax expense (income);</li>
    <li>any adjustments recognised in the period for current tax of prior periods;</li>
    <li>any amounts of deferred tax expenses (income) relating to the origination and reversal of temporary differences;</li>
    <li>the amount of deferred tax expense (income) relating to changes in tax rates or the imposition of new taxes;</li>
    <li>the amount of the benefit arising from a previously unrecognised tax loss, tax credit or temporary difference of a prior period that is used to reduce current tax expense;</li>
    <li>the amount of the benefit arising from a previously unrecognised tax loss, tax credit or temporary difference of a prior period that is used to reduce deferred  tax expense;</li>
    <li>deferred tax expense arising from the write-down, or reversal of a previous written-down, or a deferred tax asset to reflect its recoverable amount (IAS 12.56);</li>
    <li>the amount of tax expense (income) relating to those changes in accounting policies and errors that are included in profit or loss in accordance with IAS, because they cannot be accounted for retrospectively.</li>
</ul>
